metadata.title: Geotechnical properties of the soils modified with nanomaterials: A comprehensive review

sections.text:
Review
Geotechnical properties of the soils modified with nanomaterials: A comprehensive review
Navid Ghasabkolaei a, Asskar Janalizadeh Choobbasti a, Nader Roshan a, Seiyed E. Ghasemi b,* aDepartment of Civil Engineering, Babol University of Technology, Babol, Iran bYoung Researchers and Elite Club, Sari Branch, Islamic Azad University, Sari, Iran
1. Introduction (2) Creating and using structures, tools, and systems that have
new properties and performances due to their small size or

a b s t r a c t
In recent years, large steps have been taken in the field of nanotechnology, and many nanotechnology-based breakthroughs have been made in geotechnical engineering. It is apparent that nanomaterials will be used to improve the geotechnical properties of soils in the near future, extensively.
In this paper, we discussed previous studies on the use of nanoparticles in soil, their properties, their effects on soil and the equipment used in nanotechnology. A new categorization was introduced and the significant effects of nanoparticles on the properties of soil were studied. According to the new categorization, clay particles vary between 0.1 and 2 mm, while nanosol contains particles in the range of 1–100 nm.

The ideas and concepts behind nanoscience and nanotechnology started with a talk entitled ‘‘There's Plenty of Room at the Bottom’’ by physicist Richard Feynman at an American Physical Society meeting at the California Institute of Technology on December 1959, long before the term nanotechnology was used [1,2]. Since then, various definitions have been proposed for nanotechnology. The National Nanotechnology Initiative (NNI) presented a comprehensive definition that includes the following three definitions: [3]
(1) Technology development and research at atomic, molecular, or macro-molecular levels on the scale of 1–100 nm;

medium limit; (3) Ability to control or manipulate at atomic levels.
Utilizing the properties of nanoscale material provides some characteristics, advantages and profits that are fundamental from medical, scientifical, environmental and commercial. Among the benefits that have been recognized to date are reducing energy consumption, economic savings, time savings, increased quality of products, all of which can contribute to increased quality of life and healthier lifestyles. They can also reduce our dependence on other advanced technologies and their higher costs and increase the national

income. Unfortunately, the amazing effect of nanotechnology and its use have not been recognized well to date in geotechnical engineering. Perhaps this is due to the fact that nanotechnology studies are of interdisciplinary nature, which requires researchers to have wide range knowledge to understand the extended necessities of nanotechnology and to determine their roles in this new and exciting field [4]. However, in recent years, some significant steps have been taken to evaluate the potential uses of this technology in geotechnical engineering and given the promising results of these studies, it should not be surprising when this technology is embraced and utilized in geotechnical engineering.
In this paper, we describe the ‘‘nanosol’’ concept, which is a new classification of soil. Then, we discuss the equipment used to analyze the structure of soil and some cases in which nanoparticles can be used to improve the geotechnical properties of soil. Therefore, nano particles can be entitled as an additive for stabilization of soils.
2. Soil classification based on nano-approach
Soil is any uncemented or weakly-cemented accumulation of mineral particles [5] with size ranging from as small as 1 nm to as large as 75 mm [6]. Such a wide range of particle sizes has made soil one of the most complicated materials to study, understand, model, and utilize. In classical geotechnical engineering, four categories of soil are generally recognized, i.e., gravel, sand, silt, and clay; the dimensions of which are provided in Table 1 [7].
Although this classification has solved two problems related to soil mechanics. First, as the sizes of the particles decrease to the nanoscale, their properties can change dramatically. Second, according to the classical definition, clay particles include particles smaller than 2 mm, which means that the sizes of clay particles range from 1 nm to 2 mm. Therefore, the ratio of the size of the largest particles to the size of the smallest particles is 2 10 6/1 10 9 = 2000, which is much greater ratio than for other fractions. Thus, Zhange [7] proposed the new range of 0.1–2 mm for clay particles, giving them a ratio of 20. In so doing, the ratio was changed from 2000 to 20, which is about the same as the ratio for other fractions. Similarly, in the proposed new definition, the sizes of nanoparticles were designated to be in the range of 1– 100 nm, giving them a ratio of 100. Thus, a new category of particles, called ‘‘nanosol,’’ was devised to define these soil nanoparticles that have properties that are remarkably different from those of clay [7].

sections.heading: 3. Applying nanomechanics in geotechnical engineering
sections.text:
The concept of nanomechanics is related to geotechnical engineering for the following reasons:
Soil and rock minerals are nanomaterials: nanoparticles exist in soil environment, including smectite, imogolite, halloysite, palygorskite, sepiolite, allophane, hematite, and goethite [7]. Nanomechanics can be used to gain a better understanding of the mechanical behavior of soil and rock (e.g. friction, creep, thermal effects, and chemical effects): nanoparticles interact very actively with other soil constituents (including the liquid phase, cations, organic matter and clay minerals) due to their exceptionally high specific surface area (SSA) (i.e., the total surface area per unit mass) and reactive surfaces with charges, and thus they have profound influence on the microstructure and the physical, chemical and engineering properties of soils, even when they represent only a very small weight fraction of the material [7]. Nanomechanics can predict the behaviors of geotechnical materials in special conditions: The soils are natural materials that possess complex physical and chemical properties, so predicting the behavior of soil definitely is challenging, even with modern geotechnical engineering techniques [8]. The interaction of soils and rocks with fluids (e.g., weathering) is a nanoprocess: Some nanoparticles are porous and contain intraparticle-nanoscale voids. The presence of nanoporosity significantly increases the SSA and hence the absorption capacity (e.g., water retention, organic absorption) and also reduces bulk density. Therefore, porous nanoparticles can influence soil properties very dramatically, even when they are present as a very small weight fraction [7].
Clay is a nanomaterial and the behavior of its particles is controlled by nanomechanics [9].

sections.heading: 4. Equipment used to study the nanostructure of soil particles
sections.text:
The microscopic structure of fine-grained soils can be used as an index to identify diverse environments and evaluate their strength [10].
New methods have been proposed for observing the structure of soils at the nanometric scale. The transmission electron microscope (TEM), scanning electron microscope (SEM), and atomic force microscope (AFM) are among the direct methods for taking images of nanoscale particles, and they provide information concerning their dimensions, shapes, and morphologies [11,12].
SEM was invented in 1931 by Knoll and Ruska. It provides larger images using electrons. In this method, an electron ray perpendicularly shines on the specimen. As an interaction between the ray and specimen in vacuum, electrons and Xrays are emitted. Sensors receive the emitted X-rays, the initial electrons, and the electrons that result from the interactions of the initial electrons. The sensors convert them into signals and transmit the signals to monitors that provide the final image
[13]. This method can be also used to investigate the sizes and distributions of the nanoparticles [14–16].
TEM was invented in 1939 by two German scientists, Siemens and Halska, to simplify the analysis process and improve the accuracy of images [17]. TEM, like SEM, uses electron emissions by passing the electrons through the specimen and to a phosphorus detector to provide a plan of the specimen's structure [18]. TEM is able to take images of the nanoscale particles that are produced so that the sizes and morphologies of the particles can be scrutinized. It also can be used to study inorganic materials in soils [19]. In addition, it enables the identification and analysis of features on a significantly sub-micrometer scale [20].
AFM was invented in 1986 by Binning, Quate, and Gerber [21]. It has many applications in determining surface topography and studying surface cavities [22]. AFM consists of a cantilever with a sharp tip at its end that is used to scan the specimen's surface. Unlike an electron microscope, which provides a two-dimensional projection or a two-dimensional image of a sample, AFM provides a true three-dimensional profile of the surface. High resolution AFM is comparable to SEM and TEM. AFM images are used in geotechnical engineering to study the roughness of surfaces and the friction angle between soil particles [23,24]. A major advantage of AFM is that, unlike electron microscopes, it can operate in air, vacuum, and liquid environments [22]. This technique is still relatively new to study the nanostructures of cementitious materials [25–31].

sections.heading: 5. Practical records of using nanoparticles in soils
5.1.1. Colloidal silica
sections.text:
Yonekora and Miwa [32] determined unconfined compressive strength of 335 kPa in sand grouted with 32 wt% (weight percent) colloidal silica. In a pilot study, Noll et al. [33] obtained reduced permeability and metal absorption by using colloidal silica gel that contained loose sand. After 5 wt% of colloidal silica treatment, the permeability ranges from 10 8 to 10 7 cm/ s. The study by Persoff et al. [34] indicated that the compressive strength of sand increased as the concentration of colloidal silica in the grout was increased up to 27 wt% after seven days, reaching approximately 400 kPa (Fig. 1). The silica content was 4.9, 7.4, 9.8, 19.7, and 27.7%. For concentrations of silica particles greater than 7.4 wt%, the hydraulic conductivity was less than 1.0 10 1 cm/s. Also, in this range, the log of the hydraulic conductivity decreased approximately linearly with concentration of the colloidal silica particles.
Towhata and Kabashima [35] conducted triaxial tests and studied the reduction of foundation subsidence on liquefiable sand. They reported that specimens with 40% relative density treated with 4.5 wt% of colloidal silica exhibited deformation behavior and liquefaction resistance similar to those of untreated dense sand with relative density of 75% or more. Gallagher and Mitchell [36] showed that 5 wt% of colloidal silica considerably mitigated the risk of liquefaction of loose sand in case of seismic loading. When strain limitation was
targeted, 10 wt% provided sufficient stabilization with acceptable strain levels. Although using more than 10 wt% colloidal silica limited the strain even further, it was not economically feasible (Fig. 2).
Also, Rodriguez and Izarraras [37] investigated the reduction of liquefaction potential of liquefiable sand with colloidal silica. Adding 15 wt% of colloidal silica to liquefiable loose sand significantly increased the soil resistance against liquefaction. Thus, by adding colloidal silica grout, the behavior of treated loose sand was similar to that of dense untreated one. Kodaka et al. [38] investigated the effect of colloidal silica gel on the cyclic shear characteristics of sand. Consequently, the cyclic torsional shear test was conducted, and they found that adding 4 wt% of colloidal silica significantly decreased the strength of loose sand against liquefaction. Gallagher and Lin [39] presented a theory related to the mitigation of the liquefaction potential of loose sand. The results of their unconfined compression test indicated that 5 wt% of colloidal silica was suitable for mitigating the risk of liquefaction because the colloidal silica increased the cohesion of the sand and its resistance against liquefaction. Gallagher et al. [40] studied the stabilization of liquefiable sand using colloidal silica in the grout with centrifuge modeling. They reported that 6 wt% of colloidal silica was the optimal content for sand stabilizing. Gallagher et al. [41] injected colloidal silica gel as an additive into wells that contained sand to reduce the settling of
liquefiable soils by explosion. After the explosion, 40% less settlement was reported in the modified zones. This mechanism could be justified by the bound between colloidal silica and grains of individual sand particles. The colloidal silica gel encapsulated the soil and maintained it during dynamic loading. Spencer et al. [42] studied the effects of colloidal silica on the dynamic properties of sand, including the shear modulus and the damping ratio, using 5, 7 and 9 wt% of colloidal silica in the resonant column test. The effect of colloidal silica on the damping ratio was negligible in the applied strain range. Thus, the presence of silica gel did not affect the damping ratio significantly. By adding 5 wt% of colloidal silica, the shear modulus increased by 6 MPa over 28 days.
Rodriguez et al. [43] assessed the effect of colloidal silica on the reduction of the liquefaction potential in silty sand using the cyclic simple shear test and concluded that colloidal silica can be efficiently used to stabilize soil against liquefaction. They reported that 14.5 wt% of colloidal silica can considerably reduce pore pressure and shear strain during cyclic loading at the age of seven days. Conlee et al. [44] ran centrifuge tests to evaluate the effectiveness of colloidal silica for mitigating liquefaction. The centrifuge test evaluated the response of untreated loose sands and loose sands that were treated with 4, 5 and 9 wt% of colloidal silica. Ground deformations were reduced by adding colloidal silica; also, the shear wave velocity was greater. The centrifuge tests indicated an increase in the cyclic resistance ratio and a decrease in the cyclic shear strain when the concentration of colloidal silica was increased.

sections.heading: 5.1.2. Nanoclay
sections.text:
Ouhadi and Bakhshalipour [45] investigated the effect of nanoclays on the behavior of collapsible soil. Natural bentonite particles were smashed into nanoscale particles using a ball mill. An odometer test was conducted to evaluate the soil collapsibility. The size of the particles in the clay fraction and the plasticity index of the clay governed soil collapsibility (Fig. 3).
Mohamadzadeh Sani et al. [46] conducted Atterberg limits and direct shear tests on clayey sand specimens by varying the weight percentage (0.5, 1 and 2 wt%) of nanoclay. The results showed that the addition of nanoclay reduced the plasticity
index and increased the shear strength. When 1 wt% of nanoclay was added, the liquid limit and the plastic limit increased by 13% and 38%, respectively, and the plasticity index decreased by about 40%. Also, adding 0.5 wt% of nanoclay significantly improved the shear strength. Significant improvement was not achieved by adding more than 0.5% of nanoclay. According to special application, if it is necessary, nanoclay can be used to decrease the plasticity index. For this purpose, more research is needed on this particular application of nanoparticle for scientific purpose (Fig. 4).
Arabani et al. [47] studied the use of nanoclay to improve the mechanical properties of sand stabilized with cement using the unconfined compressive strength (UCS) test and the California bearing ratio (CBR) test. A cement percentage of 7 wt % of the dry weight of soil and nanoclay contents of 0.5, 1, 2, 3, and 5 wt% were used in the soil. The results showed that the nanoclay improved the strength properties of the cementstabilized soil after 7, 14, and 28 days. They reported that, by adding 2 wt% of nanoclay, the elastic modulus in tension increased from 7.6 to 11.23 MPa after 28 days of curing. Also, after 7 days of curing, the CBR values increased from 84.66 to 112.75. When a small quantity of nanoclay were uniformly dispersed in the cement mortar, during hydration, the hydrate products will deposit on the nano particles due to their great surface energy and grow to form conglomeration containing the nano particles as nucleus.
Janalizadeh et al. [48] studied the permeability of silty sand improved with nanoclay with falling head tests. The specimens were prepared by mixing soil with 0.25, 0.5, and 1 wt% of nanoclay. Fig. 5 shows that, by adding nanoclay to soil, a remarkable reduction of permeability occurred with maximum reduction with 0.25 wt% of nanoclay. Adding nanoclay to soil increased the fine content and filled the voids between larger particles, which reduced the facility of water movement via decreasing the porosity.

sections.heading: 5.2.1. Carbon nanotube (CNT)
sections.text:
Taha and Ying [49] studied the effect of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) on the geotechnical behavior of kaolinite soil. Atterberg limit and consolidation tests were conducted for ranges from 0
to 0.5 wt% by dry weight of CNTs and 0–1% by dry weight, respectively. Fig. 9 shows that the addition of CNT to the mixture increased the plasticity index by 22%. Also, the compression index increased by 32% and the swelling index by 11%. Hydraulic conductivity was however reduced.

sections.heading: 5.2.2. Nano alumina
sections.text: Luo et al. [50] investigated the use of nano alumina oxide to stabilize cohesive soil with sewage sludge ash/cement. The intended mix ratio for sewage sludge ash and cement was 3:1. In this study, 15% of the clay soil was replaced by sewage sludge ash/cement to produce the treated soil and nano-Al2O3 contents of 0, 1, 2 and 3 wt% was applied. The effect of nanoAl2O3 was studied including Atterberg limits, unconfined compressive strength (UCS), swell potential, and California bearing ratio (CBR). It was found that 1% nano-Al2O3 was the optimum amount to add to the mixture of sewage sludge ash/ cement. This shows that the UCS of the soil treated with 1% nano-Al2O3 was 4.2 higher than that of untreated one after seven days of curing. The PI value for 1% nano-Al2O3 was smaller than for the others. Also, the smallest swell potential was observed for soil treated with 1% nano-Al2O3. The CBR values for treated soil with 0 and 1% nano-Al2O3were 60.2 and 70.1, respectively.

sections.heading: 5.2.3. Nanoclay
sections.text:
Baziar et al. [51] assessed the effect of adding nanoclay on the plasticity properties of clayey soil. In order to do so, 1, 2, 4 and 8 wt% nanoclay was added to clay, and the results were compared with those of nano-free soil. Fig. 11 shows that the nanoclay had no considerable effect on the plastic limit, but it increased the liquid limit. Also, adding nanoclay increased the plasticity index. Adding 8 wt% nanoclay resulted in a 60% increase in the plasticity index, which was considerable. This issue can be useful in many geotechnical projects, like the clay core of earth dams, because a high plasticity index can reduce the risk of cracks formation, increases the resistance against piping and the stability of the dam. Ghazi et al. [52] studied the compressive strength of clay treated with nanoclay. The
addition levels of nanoclay were 2, 4, and 8 wt%. For the nanoclay content of 8 wt%, the compressive strength increased from 389.01 to 521.99 kPa, which resulted in a total 34.2% increase that decreased ductility and increased stiffness.
Kananizadehn et al. [53] studied the effect of nanoclay on permeability reduction of clay (case study of the Kahrizak landfill). The specimens were prepared by mixing soil with 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 wt% of nanoclay and using the falling head permeability test. It was found that nanoclay addition decreased the plasticity index. Adding 4 wt% nanoclay was tested as optimum percentage to reduce permeability to 7.74 10 11 cm/s and the thickness of the lining layer was reduced to 0.6 m due to economic concern. Swelling was also reduced (Fig. 6).
Taha and Taha [54] studied the effect of nanomaterial on the expansion and shrinkage behaviors of soil. Each one of three types of nanoparticles, i.e., nanoclay, nano-alumina, and nano-copper nanoparticles, were mixed with the clayey soil at 0.05, 0.075, 0.1, 0.15, and 0.3 wt%. They found that adding the optimum percentage of nanomaterial decreased the volumetric strains (shrinkage and expansion strains) and reduced the crack intensity factor (CIF) without any decrease in hydraulic conductivity. Shrinkage and expansion strains in soil result in cracks, which increase the permeability, thereby reducing the resistance against sliding. In this case, the nanoclay particles had very little effect on the properties of the soil, and sometimes their effect was negative rather than positive.
Improvement with nano-copper, due to reduced volumetric strains, was better than that of nano-alumina because the particle density of nano-copper was greater. When the nanoalumina particles were used in the mixture, the specific gravity of the mixture was higher, and this led to an increase in maximum dry density. Thus, shrinkage and expansion strains were reduced. Moreover, the increase of agglomerated particles content led to dry density decrease and voids increase, which the water content increased. Nano-copper particles were twice the size of the nano-alumina particles and nano-copper particles had lower density. Thus, nano-copper is a better option for improving the soil. Majeed and Taha [55] studied the geotechnical properties of soft soil with 0.1, 0.2, and 0.3 wt% nanoclay. The Atterberg limits and the plasticity index decreased and the maximum dry density of the soil increased. With nanoclay content, the strength properties of soil were also improved.
Nikookar et al. [56] studied the strength characteristics of silt (ML and MH) stabilized with nanoclay. In their study, unconfined compressive strength (UCS) and California bearing ratio (CBR) tests were conducted on specimens that contained 0.5, 1, 1.5, and 2 wt% nanoclay. Fig. 7 shows that the optimum contents of nanoclay for ML and MH were 1.5 and 1 wt%, respectively. The CBR values for the untreated soil were 8 and 5 for ML and MH, respectively. Adding 1.5 and 1 wt% of nanoclay to ML and MH increased the CBR values to 36 and 16, respectively.
When small amounts of the nanoclay were uniformly dispersed in the soil, nanoparticles can improve the strength through the filling effect. In other words, nanoclay as filler for void between particles, create a micro structure in soil, therefore soil strength increases.
Bahari et al. [57] studied the stabilization of silt (ML and MH) by adding nanoclay to the specimens at 0.5, 1, 1.5, and 2 wt% in order to analyze the improvements in the geotechnical properties of the stabilized silt. Fig. 8 shows that the nanoclay increased the liquid limit and the plastic limit of the silt. As a result, an increase in nanoclay content leads to increase in both angle of internal friction and cohesion. The results of direct shear tests also showed that 1.5 wt% nanoclay in ML increased its cohesion value by 93% (from 7.5 to 14 kPa) while the internal friction angle increased by 68. The cohesion value of MH increased up to about 62% (from 13 to 21 kPa), and the internal friction angle increased by 68.
Fazeli et al. [58] studied the rehabilitation of collapsible soil with nanoclay at levels of 5, 10, 15, and 20 wt%. Fig. 9 shows that increasing nanoclay percentage resulted in decreasing the collapsible index intensity. Thus, the issue of the collapsibility of ML can be improved by using up to 20 wt% nanoclay.
Zahedi et al. [59] studied the resistance to freezing cycles of clay modified with nanoclay at levels of 0%, 1.5%, 3%, 4.5% and 6% by weight. Adding nanoclay will increase SSA, which can be partly cause of non-effective increasing nanoclay in soil resistance. Also, freezing cycle effects the soil compressive strength. They reported compressive strength of soil with 4.5% nanoclay in more than all. Increasing levels of freezing cycle decreases the soil resistance (Fig. 10).

sections.heading: 5.2.4. Nanosilica
sections.text:
Ghazavi and Bolhasani [60] prepared cylindrical clay specimens with 1, 3, and 5 wt% lime and 0, 3, 5, and 7 wt% nanosilica. The unconfined compressive strength (UCS) test was conducted on the specimens containing lime and nanosilica at wet curing times of 7, 28, and 90 days. The results indicate that nanosilica alone had no effect on strength in the short term, but as these particles were active, the pozzolanic reaction was initiated if they contained lime particles and the strength increased considerably (Fig. 11). Compressive strength of the improved clay increased with time.
Ghazi et al. [61] investigated the effect of adding nanosilica on the compressive strength of clay soil stabilized with 6% cement, and the results indicated that there was a significant strengths increase of the specimens that contained 0.5, 1, and 2 wt% of nanosilica. By adding 2% nanosilica, the strength increased from 1645.49 to 2346.83 kPa, so 42.6% increase. Seyedi Gelsefidi and Mamaghanian [62] studied the compressive strength of clay soil improved with nanosilica. 5 wt% of Lime was added, and the nanosilica contents of the clayey soil–lime mixture were 1, 3, and 5 wt%. The results indicated that the addition of nanosilica is very effective in improving the UCS of the soil–lime mixture. According to results 3% nanosilica was selected as the optimum amount, when the UCS of the soil–lime mixture increased up to three times more than that of the nanofree specimens after 28 days of curing
(Fig. 12). A significant increase was observed with curing time of UCS for the mixture containing nanosilica.
Bahmani et al. [63] studied the effect of nanosilica on Atterberg limits, hydraulic conductivity and the compressive strength of cement-treated residual soil. The specimens were prepared using kaolinite clay with 4, 6, and 8% cement with 0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.8, and 1% nanosilica (Fig. 13). The results indicate that the addition of nanosilica reduced PI. The specimen with 0.4% nanosilica exhibited a significant (80%) increase in its compressive strength. The lowest conductivity among the specimens occurred when 0.4% nanosilica was added.
Ghasabkolaei et al. [64] investigated the effect of nanosilica on geotechnical properties of cement-treated clayey soil. The cement percentage used in the clayey soil was 9%. To disperse Nanosilica in the water, Ultrasonic device has been used. Nanosilica was added in percentages of 1, 1.5, 2 and 3%, by weight of cement. To control strength parameters of soil, Unconfined Compressive Strength and California Bearing Ratio (CBR) tests were performed.
They found that small amount of nanosilica investigated (1.5% by weight of cement) produced a significant (38%) strength increase of cement treated clay (Fig. 14). Also, the incremental rate of compressive strength was greater during the first seven days, after which the increasing trend gradually became slower. When it mixed with cement-treated clayey soil, the cement hydration is accelerated due to their high activity.
The images of scanning electron microscope (SEM) were used to verify the results. According to the SEM images (Fig. 15), the specimens that contain nanosilica were denser and more homogeneous than the nanofree specimens. The following
explanation is a key reason for the improvement of soil strength.

sections.heading: 5.2.5. Other nanosoils
sections.text:
Taha [65] investigated the effect of nanosoil obtained from ball mill operations on the geotechnical properties of soil.
Fig. 15 – SEM images of the specimens: (a) specimen treated with nanosilica.
Atterberg limits and unconfined compressive strength (UCS) tests were conducted on kaolinite soil after nanosoil was added. The soil–nanosoil mixture was prepared by mixing 98% of the original soil and 2% nanosoil by weight. In order to investigate the effects of the nanosoil on the strength of the cement–soil mixture, 1 and 2 wt% amounts of nanosoil were added, and the liquid limit increased less than the plastic limit, and consequently the plasticity index decreased. After seven days of curing, compressive strengths of the 0, 1, and 2 wt% nanosoil specimens were 689, 1149, and 1493 kPa, respectively. After soil mixing with 4% cement and 2% nanosoil the compressive strength of the specimen was twice higher than for the nanofree specimen (Fig. 16).
Khalid et al. [66] studied the influence of nanosoil produced from pulverization process on soft soil stabilization. Atterberg limits, unconfined compressive strength and direct shear tests were conducted after 2%, 3% and 4% nanosoil was added. Addition of 2–4% nanosoil increased the compressive strength of sandy silt from 3% to 22% and the angle of internal friction from 7% to 17%. However, the addition of nanosoil decreases the plasticity index (Fig. 17).

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this paper, we traced the advances of nanotechnology in geotechnical engineering. Soil mechanics embraced a new category of soil particles called ‘‘nanosol’’ in a scale of 1– 100 nm in order to separate them from clay particles. In order to investigate the nanostructures of soils SEM, TEM, and AFM imaging methods were used.
Nanoparticles have novel properties because of their extremely small size resulting in extremely high specific surface areas (SSA) and surface charges. As a result, these particles react very actively with other particles in the soil matrix.
The presence of even very small amount of nanomaterial can have significant effects on the engineering properties of soil.
The use of nanoparticles in a soil mixture increases strength, swelling index and compressibility as well as decreases permeability, liquefaction potential, settlement and volumetric strains.
It should be noted that the behaviors of nanomaterial vary, depending on the type of particles and the soil they are mixed. Table 2 provides the results obtained by various researchers. This table contains information that can be useful when the soil to be stabilized with nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 7. Possible future studies
sections.text:
1. Assessing the geotechnical properties of soils treated with chemical additives and nanoparticles. 2. Assessing the simultaneous effects of nanosilica and microsilica on the geotechnical properties of soil. 3. Research involving the use of nanoparticles with problematic soils. 4. Effect of nanoparticles on the durability of soil stabilized with chemical additives by wetting–drying and freezing– thawing cycles. 5. Development of behavioral models of the soils stabilization with chemical additives and nanoparticles.

metadata.abstractText: In recent years, large steps have been taken in the field of nanotechnology, and many nanotechnology-based breakthroughs have been made in geotechnical engineering. It is apparent that nanomaterials will be used to improve the geotechnical properties of soils in the near future, extensively. In this paper, we discussed previous studies on the use of nanoparticles in soil, their properties, their effects on soil and the equipment used in nanotechnology. A new categorization was introduced and the significant effects of nanoparticles on the properties of soil were studied. According to the new categorization, clay particles vary between 0.1 and 2 mm, while nanosol contains particles in the range of 1–100 nm. © 2017 Politechnika Wrocławska.
